title: Energy conservation - pt charge and 3 test charges

content.question:
A positive point charge <math alttext="positive uppercase Q" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math> is fixed in place, as shown in the figure. The stationary point charge and points <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>, and <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> all lie along a straight line, with the three labeled points at the indicated distances from the point charge. Three different test charges are released from rest, one at a time, at either Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> or Point <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math> as follows.

Test Charge <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and positive charge <math alttext="positive lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mpadded></math>. It is released at Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>.

Test Charge <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has mass <math alttext="the fraction M over 2" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>M</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> and positive charge <math alttext="positive 2 times lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>q</mi></mpadded></math>. It is released at Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math>.

Test Charge <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> has mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and negative charge <math alttext="negative 2 times lowercase q" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>q</mi></mpadded></math>. It is released at Point <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></math>.

Each test charge moves toward Point <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math> after being released. Which of the following correctly ranks the kinetic energies <math alttext="K sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="K sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="K sub 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math> of the test charges when each is at Point <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="K sub 1 equals K sub 2, which equals K sub 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="K sub 2 is greater than K sub 1, which equals K sub 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="K sub 3 is greater than K sub 1, which equals K sub 2" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>

<math alttext="K sub 3 is greater than K sub 2, which is greater than K sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="K sub 2 is greater than K sub 1, which equals K sub 3" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></math>
